reviewText:
To preface this review, I have beat the game. This review is not out of frustration for not being able to accomplish that, but it is out of frustration from the game in general.

For a match 3 game the concept is novel, adding a requirement of matching specific tiles to progress.

Unfortunately once the novelty wears off, it becomes a chore. And the novelty will wear off, because the game is stacked against you in multiple ways, and requires you to lose repeatedly to complete tasks and buy upgrades (which soon become an artificial barrier to gameplay) before winning it even becomes possible.

The main barrier to fun in the game is the manner of losing - not the inevitability, as with Tetris, but the speed at which it can happen. Every obstacle requires a specific type of match - attacks or keys - and the game can at whim decide to deprive you of these, leaving you helpless to do anything but wait until defeat.

Other problems with the control system compound this. For instance, sliding the tiles is not well designed. If you click a tile, it can only slide by the first direction the mouse moves. So if you want to drag a tile upwards but your mouse moves a LITTLE to the left first, your tiles will try moving left and right instead. You can try again while the mouse button is held down, but you've lost that time.

The matching detection is not great either. When you line or nearly line up a match, their tiles illuminate, however when you let go the tile you're moving can fit to an adjacent space, meaning the match does not occur and you have to start again. Once more, this costs time.

The game needs resource management - trying to keep a healthy number of attack tiles and keys on the board at all times to be ready for any obstacles that arrive, but a couple of things ruin this as a concept and make the game even less fun.

The monsters - particularly boss class monsters - require a LOT of matches and items to defeat, during which time you're losing time AND they hit you which also costs a nasty chunk of time. It goes without saying that despite the whole upgrade system, matching attack tiles is just not effective enough to keep the game balanced.

The game can and does throw numerous amounts of the same obstacles at you consecutively, such as two chests, a door and then another chest. Even if you kept a healthy number of keys available at the start of this, you probably won't have enough to get through it all which leads to a lot of lost time and defeat. The same applies to multiple tough monsters.

Matching tiles or using an item JUST before you arrive at an obstacle will cause it to be wasted. There's no tolerance whatsoever. This can lead to situations where you're not blocked by an obstacle, and too afraid to do anything because you don't want to lose the matches you can see available to you. This is contrary to the game's advertised element.

Finally, when you match tiles, more appear which can result in combos. Normally in this kind of game these are desirable, but in this game they can and will punish you by decimating a resource you can see yourself needing soon - for instance, if you're fighting a monster with a chest behind it, a few keys may fall in during the fight, matching with the ones already on the board and severely depleting the keys. Then when you win the fight you won't be able to deal with the chest.

Furthermore, when newly-fallen tiles create combos, this takes time during which you are unable to slide any tiles to make more matches. This results in awkward situations where you can see multiple matches you want to make but are unable to do so because a useless combo is ongoing and killing you in the process.

You do get a very limited number of items, but most of the time an item does not even clear one of its respective obstacles. After a few hours of play to finally be able to challenge for the game's namesake 10,000,000 points (yes, you need to play for a few hours before winning a game even becomes a possibility), key items will not be enough to open a three-lock chest or door, and you will need at least three damage items to defeat a single monster.

This game had promise, but its execution is disastrous. Its visuals and music are very fun for a few hours, but they do not last the extended periods of time demanded of you when the game becomes an unfair and repetitive grind.

reviewText:
10000000 is a game that mixes the match-3 genre with an RPG angle. Now, it's not as enjoyable as the Puzzle Quest games but the game is not a complete trainwreck either. Despite the horrible controls (or morel like 'control' - it's mouse only and 'slide'-based, naturally intended for a smartphone device), it can serve you a bit of fun for a couple of hours. However, if you're out to get all of the achievements then you might be in for a long and painful grind. This is due to the very annoying RNG.

All the negativity aside, let's get more into how the game works. You start out with a simple character, trapped in a place with barred up doors. You want to break free from this prison, but to do so, you must get a 10 000 000 score. Simple, right? Well, not really. Your toon is weak and in order to become stronger and advance then you need to gather supplies and gold. How do you do that? Well, that's where the core of the game comes in! You will need to arm yourself and venture into the dungeons!

At first, you'll see the familiar match 3 board and you'll start to match tiles as you would in any type of game like this. Soon you will notice that you're not only meant to match them, you're meant to match certain tiles at certain times. Your toon will encounter foes with different abilities and weaknesses, knowing when to match the sword or the staff tiles might save you a lot of trouble here! There are also locks on chests and doors that you need to open by matching keys. Sometimes you will gain an item or a consumable by opening chests, but also if you match the chests on the tile board. These you can use to help you progress in the dungeons. Then there are the wood and stones that you need to upgrade the different shops.

I had a lot of fun with the game in the beginning, especially when it felt like you made progress. Each new rank you unlock is a higher difficulty, and with each ranks there are several challenges to complete that grants you various bonuses. However, when you've reached the highest rank and completed all of the bonuses then the game kind of loses its potential. It takes a lot of luck and patience to even reach a score of 10 million, in any rank. I managed to 100% the game after nearly 13 hours of playtime. I've read about people who still hasn't been able to even after 30 hours, so keep this in mind if you're looking for an easy game to get perfect.

Despite all the flaws and lack of fun end game I enjoyed it when I didn't feel too stressed out. The further you get, the quicker you need to be to match the tiles. You need to be able to notice when the border of your board turns red (encounters/events) or green (when your toon is mainly walking) and adapt to this in the best way possible. It takes time getting used to how the game functions, especially when it comes to matching the tiles by sliding the columns and rows. It can be extremely frustrating at times and I wish the developer had thought about this when porting the game to PC. It's already a challenging game and believe me, being defeated just because you weren't able to align the tiles perfectly due to whatever or any reason is just flat out aggrivating.

I can recommend it if you like casual games that are a bit of a challenge. 10000000 is a challenge, both physically and mentally. In a good or bad way? Well, a bit of both to be honest.

A surprisingly fun game, 10,000,000 gave me more far more enjoyment than I had expected when I initially purchased it for a few dollars.  Though the game is primarily a Match-Three, every single type that you match provides an effect that drastically alters your current encounter.  Match three (or more for an increased effect) swords, for example, and you'll unleash a physical attack; match three magic wands, you'll cast a magical attack; match three keys, you'll unlock a treasure chest or door, etc.

The game is quite challenging, though each time you run through a dungeon path you'll acquire gold, experience, and items that will aid you in future runs.  Gold can be used to upgrade your equipment (swords, staves, shields, armor, etc.) by choosing a specific trait such as the sharpness of your sword (critical chance) or the material that it is made out of (base damage).  Experience can be used to purchase training upgrades which enhance abilities such as your lockpicking skills and increasing damage against certain enemy types.

All in all, it's a cheap game with a good amount of fun to be had as long as you keep that in mind.

While the game delivered less depth than the concept seemed to allow for, I still got a very fast-paced, addictive, and satisfying puzzler. The music was catchy, and the variety of things to level up provided enough incentive to make it through most of the game. What I most appreciated was the fact that you're unlikely to brute force your way to the 10,000,000 point goal by simply grinding enough to level everything. Success is ultimately the result of strategy, speed, and good fortune, which was refreshing after the way so many other smartphone ports that have made it to this platform just hand victory to the player after a significant enough investment of time and virtual currency. It's unlikely that you'll want to revisit this one after beating it, but the asking price is very reasonable for a game of 10,000,000's overall quality.

reviewText:
10,000,000 is an arcade match-3 RPG with base management mechanics. Now, that may sound schizophrenic, but all the features actually mold together quite well to create a strange but fun experience. The gameplay consists mostly of dragging rows of cubes in order to match 3 of a certain type of cube, thereby helping you pass whatever obstacle you are currently faced with. Unfortunately, the game often gives you tons of whatever you need the least of at a certain time, leading to quite a lot of frustration. I remember one run in which I started out with a ton of keys.
“Yeah!” I thought. “I’ll be totally set for this run!”
I was then presented with about  10 or 15 obstacles in a row that required keys, and I ran out about halfway through and had to simply bide my time until the one match that I needed came along, using up all of my special items and powerups in the process. Now, whether that was built into the engine or I just have the worst luck in the world remains to be seen, but that kind of thing happens extremely frequently.
The gameplay sometimes gets as annoying as the music (an extremely loud 8-bit tune in an endless loop), with the aforementioned situation of having everything except the one thing that you need providing nearly endless frustration. The goal of the game is to get 10,000,000 points in a single run, because apparently that will help you somehow escape the prison you are in. While in a run, you can collect special items for use in a pinch, as well as building materials, gold, and experience. You can use the building materials to fix and upgrade your base. What benefit do base upgrades give? They help you waste all your gold and XP getting upgrades for your equipment.
Later on in the game, the price of training skills and getting upgrades becomes completely outrageous, whilst you are left sitting on a huge pile of wood and stone with nothing to spend it on. One thing I did like about the game was the difficulty curve. As you gather more points and complete objectives, you rank up and are forced to face harder and harder monsters. Thankfully, this gives the game a natural flow. Every time you rank up, the super-hard boss monsters that used to always kill you before you could get any matches in become commonplace grunts.
Overall, 10,000,000 is a fun game, and it is definitely worth 5 bucks for the hours of gameplay you will undoubtedly get from it. While many players like me will ragequit often, you’ll always be coming back for more. I hope we can see a more polished and less frustrating sequel sometime in the future.

reviewText:
10,000,000 is one of those great little casual time wasters that you can pick every once in a while to grind for 5 more minutes then put back down again until the next time. The core gameplay mechanic is the basic tile matching we've seen in so many games by now, 10,000,000's own little unique aspect to this rather tired mechanic is that instead of moving individual tiles you move entire columns. This however does not change the concept significantly and if you have played a tile matching game in the past you'll figure this one out in no time at all.

The interesting aspect of 10,000,000. And what separates it from so many other similar games, is the way it approaches the timing mechanic. on top of your screen you have a little guy running along in a dungeon, as he progresses he will encounter various obstacles such as doors and monsters each pushing him slowly out of the screen if you do not match the right tiles on the board below. This creates quite a bit more purpose than your usual tile matcher where you just match what you can, as quickly as you can. Here you might wanna save those keys in case you run into a chest, or be careful not to spend too many swords and staffs if you think you're getting close to a tough monster.

The game also feature a small metagame, as you match tiles and progress through the dungeon you earn wood, stone, gold and experience which can be used to open up shops and improve your various abilities.

All in all 10,000,000 is a fun little game, nothing spectacular, nothing really exciting but a solid time waster. Unfortunately while the time waster genre as such is perfect for mobile games it does not fit quite as well on the PC and although this one of the best examples I've seen in a long time it still doesn't quite measure up to the standards that you would expect from a game that costs money.

reviewText:
10,000,000 is a primitive gauntlet running match 3 puzzle game. Your mission is to ultimately score 10,000,000 points to free yourself from the dungeon, but you have to purchase a bunch of upgrades using gold and experience points before you will be able to achieve that goal. Upgrades are available for your sword, staff, armor, and shield. Plus you can buy additional training attributes through earned experience points. Then there are the potions which have both positive and negative effects that you must weigh to determine whether to activate them or not.

The gameplay consists of frantically matching gems to attack or unlock doors and chests in an effort to keep your character from hitting the left edge of the screen. Your character continues running to the right as long as you match the right gems to vanquish your enemies or open doors and chests.

There is no polish on this game whatsoever. The concept is nice, but the game itself is pretty cheesy. However, for a buck, is does provide reasonable entertainment value.

reviewText:
10,000,000. An RPGish, Bejeweled-like game. Well... ok...

While the game does have an interesting concept it annoyingly relies on luck and what tiles the game decides to generate more than anything else, much like Bejeweled or similar puzzle games. If a monster is in your path, you'll have to quickly match sword or staff tiles to do damage. A locked chest requires matching key tiles. And as tiles are random, one might find oneself stuck, matching any tiles at all, hoping to match enough of what is needed before time is up.

At the start of the game, be prepared to lose, quite often, until enough materials are gathered to unlock upgrades. While initially the upgrades that can be purchased come in handy and allow one to make quick work of monsters, the upgrades have a max level which in my opinion is too low. Especially during the latter ranks, and especially when fighting bosses. Even completely maxed out requires, more often than not, way too many tile matches and wastes way too much time. However, there are items to find thru out the dungeon run which can help somewhat. Scrolls that will change wood or stone tiles to keys, swords, or staves. Various weapons and orbs to hurl at monsters. Skeleton keys to easily unlock chests or locks. And food items that will give you a time boost. With that said, the weapons, orbs and skeleton keys must be used rather precisely; if used a split second too early when arriving upon a chest or monster the item does nothing and disappears. The same can be said for tiles too. It would have been nice if there was some leeway as making sure the dungeon runner is close enough to an obstacle before using items can waste valuable time, even if just a split second.

And possibly the biggest time waster in the game, combos. Match some tiles, more fall down and they match. Combo! They are sometimes handy like during a boss fight. Except when the tiles continue to fall and continue to match it becomes a potential death trap. Yes, I've lost more than once awaiting tiles to stop falling and matching others because during this time nothing else can be done. And if the reason I lost wasn't because I ran out of time, it was shortly after because the combo completely used up tiles that would have came in handy just a few seconds later.

Replay value? Prepare to spend several hours upgrading everything before even attempting a run for 10,000,000. But after one does achieve freedom by getting to a score of 10,000,000, the only reason I can think of to come back to this game would be to try for a higher personal score (no Steam leaderboards), or to earn all achievements. Personally, once I complete all the achievements I doubt I will ever play this again.

Is 10,000,000 fun? Sure, it can be. Would I recommend it? Hmm. Not at the full price of $4.99. I picked it up on sale for less than a dollar. At that price it was worth it. While I don't really want to vote thumbs down, I'm going to have to since Steam has no neutral option.

reviewText:
Match 3 style games are mostly about 'randomness' and 'luck' with only a pinch of 'skill'. As such these games will take you on an emotional roller coaster; when things don't go your way you will feel deep low's of frustration. But when things are going your way you feel elation from the accomplishment of beating the odds.
This game can be very hard, you need to be extremely quick in matching tiles. There is a sort of 'continual countdown timer' where if you do not match tiles quickly enough then your 'session' will come to an end. You can increase your session 'time' by creating a match 4 or 5 of certain tiles or by eating food. On the other hand, if enemies hit you then your 'time' will decrease.

The style of 'matching tiles' in this game is similar to 'Puzzle Kingdoms' except in this game you can slide as far as you like along the entire row or column.

You will fail alot in this game especially at the harder difficulties as the odds are stacked against you. But 'winning' every play session is not how this game works. You just take each 'play session' as far as you can; you will earn resources and experience every play session which you keep regardless. You spend this upgrading your dwellings, weapon, armor, spells, equipment, etc. So the idea is that you are playing the game for the match 3 puzzle/challenge and just let the progression happen in the background naturally.I feel this game is more for an advanced or veteran match 3 puzzle player and will not be friendly to new comers of the genre.

reviewText:
Frustrating RPG Puzzle Freedom Simulator, which while wrecks your very soul into a slobbering pathetic of lifeless drool (and will leave you contemplating your very being) offers one of the most (strangely) rewarding completions ever.

It's a simple game that on the surface should be completed within a matter of minutes - the goal is simple: Achieve 10,000,000 points in 1 one and you're free to leave. If you die your score is reset. Yet, it's not that simple. Not only do you face a string of increasingly difficult monsters on your run to freedom, you also have to overcome your own inability to match 3 or more tiles together.

So simple.
Yet so freaking difficult.
And thus addicition is born.

The feeling you can beat this game, with the secretly scoffing bellows of laughter from whatever twisted mind designed this game spur you on to play it. There's not much more to say than that.
It would probably be best enjoyed as an iOS/Android game, certainly one where you could pick and play in small time windows, rather than long drawn out PC sessions (and a quick look shows that it is available for less than £2 most of the time).

If you like puzzle games, and games that tease you with their simplicity (yet burn you with their difficulty) than this game is for you. If, however, you cannot stand iOS/Android apps, and despise their existance on Steam... avoid it.

10,000,000 looks simple and, well, it is, but it's also fun to play. It reminded me of Henry Hatsworth for the NDS, without the manual platforming elements. Sword and staff tiles will damage your enemies, wood and rock tiles will help you build your castle, backpack tiles can give you items and shield tiles will give you a shield (did you expect anything else ?). A little counter in the top right will count to 10,000,000 while you journey along. That's right, 10,000,000. That's a lot. But in fact it will take several minutes to reach it. That is, if you upgrade your entire castle and know what you're doing. It also depends on a little factor called luck. Expect to finish it in 5-10 hours.
A fun little game, worthy of your time.

reviewText:
Bejewel meets, Indiana Jones meets, RPG in this odd mix. Fight your way through hordes of monsters, while using your puzzle skill to kill them off. Who knew one day that puzzles would be the bane of dragons.


Game play: 7
The game play is solid. You start off in a stone room with broken down doors everywhere, that leads into other rooms. With these rooms, you are able to increase your static, from better armor, to better spells, to better score multipliers, to more damage. To be able to unlock each door you must run the ongoing dungeon to earn experience to gain levels and to gain gold. While running the dungeon you are given a Bejewel style puzzle game. On the top of the screen you have the character running, He’ll run into monsters, doors, and chest. That you need to match up the squares to progress further into the dungeon. You are given a time limit. You will slowly be pushed backwards to the left edge of the screen. The faster you kill monsters or unlock things the closer you get to the right side of the screen. Once you pass a certain threshold on the screen you will gain a bonus to your score as long as you keep moving ahead. Each Square has an icon that you need to match up to be able to kill monsters or unlock chest or doors. Each icon has special ability to help you progress deeper. The icons you see are, Wood, Boulder, Wand, Sword, backpack, key and shield. Wood and boulder give you materials to use to build the rooms you see at the start. Wand and sword are attacks depending on the monster they can be either be weaker or stronger vs the type you are using. The backpack can give you items to use in your inventory on the right side of the screen. The key is used to open chest and doors, the shield gives you better armor to take hits better.



On the side, you have you’re inventory where you get power ups, From faster moment, to magic attacks, to keys and weapons. They can be very useful. After you die you are able to use the gold and materials you gained from the previous run to build the rooms, or you may hold on to them until next time. The overall object of the game is to get your score to 10,000,000 (Ten million). To be able to escape.


Story: 2


There isn’t really a story going on here. You are a guy who looks like Indiana Jones who has become trapped in this dungeon that is now trying to escape. Having to fight zombies, demons, dragons and such. That’s pretty much it. This game doesn’t really need much of a story to really enjoy it.




Graphics: 6


This game takes on the retro 8-bit style. Like many other indie games that uses 8-bit. They are pretty simple as it is. The mix of colors being used range from grays, to lighter colors like reds and blues. It’s a simple pallet of colors over all. The graphics don’t pop out as anything to flashy to it. they are Kinda of flat graphics. In its own right the graphics are decent.

reviewText: It's really disappointing to see all these negative reviews for the game. It's a match 3 puzzle game (but instead of swapping two tiles, you move an entire row or column to match, so it'll take a bit to get used to), but instead of leaving it at that adds in some RPG and combat elements to keep things interesting. In short, you make runs to escape a dungeon (which happens at 10,000,000 points - spoilers!) by matching tiles; sword and staff tiles do damage to enemies you run into, key tiles open locked chests and doors, backpack tiles give items that aid you along the way, and wood/stone are resources you use to upgrade rooms in the initial area you start in. At the end of the day it's still a match 3 puzzle game, so if you're not into that this probably won't do anything to change your mind, but the system of progression it uses to keep things interesting is great. Relatively short, I guess, considering it has a definitive end, but you can keep playing after the end for more upgrades/higher scores. It kept me entertained long after completion on iOS and the PC version will likely do the same.

I've seen a lot of hating on the game for it being a grind-fest, repetitive, having barriers that force loss and such...yes, the game makes you play repeated sessions of increasingly difficult 'dungeons' for challenges that unlock gold and materials and experience to make your matches do more and to upgrade your character and such. That's the gameplay beyond the tile-matching based upon what you need to get you through the obstacle you're currently encountering at the top of the screen whether it be a monster, chest, or door. I feel like too much is expected of this title for absolutely no reason. It's a game worth the about $0.99 you'll likely pay for it and can be a quick way to pass a bit of time while your buddy walks the dog and takes out the garbage before you get back to DotA 2, TF2, etc. It's got a somewhat satisfyingly simple play that, while sometimes awkward with the mouse, doesn't frustrate simply because you aren't playing because you're 'so into it,' you're playing because you need a time sink that you can put down and pick up. For what the game's worth I'd give it a 6/10.

reviewText:
July 23, 2014 with  1 hour of game play. *

10,000,000 is a match 3, where your are in prison and you need to get a score of 10,000,000 to get free.  I hesitate to call it a story, there is a intro bit that informs on the plot and that’s all you get. You have to level up your character and prison to get multipliers to even think you’ll get that score. There is lot of rpg elements like extra objectives, leveling characters, leveling weapons, and leveling up your prison. Also there is some action elements to go along with the match 3 game play.
The rpg aspects are very minimalist. You don’t level your character automatically as you play. You have to fix up the rooms with stone and wood you have accumulated through matching. Then buy your upgrade with the ingame gold or xp. There is extra objectives, such as ‘use an ax against a monster’ or ‘match 70 in one run’ which adds a bit of twist to the otherwise very grindy gameplay.
It could be considered an action side scroller. Your 2d pixel guy runs at the top of the screen, when you get up to something then you have to match three to get past that obstacle.  There is not anyway of saving up the match. If you get a run of drops it could be bad, first it slows you down as you can not match other stuf while it is falling, and it can clear the board of items you might need later. The match 3 is also a full slider style game play, instead of a single slide, flip, or twist style match 3. The control of the slide is iffy at times, forcing you to waste more time to get past the obstacle because you weren't right over the match.
10,000,000 is a fast pace hectic match 3 with action-rpg elements. At $4.99 USD it's not a bad price if you like fast pace slide style match 3.  However if you're on the fence I would definitely wait and pick it up when its a buck or as part of a packaged deal. I would give 10,000,000 a 2 out of 5.

* I’d have more time on the game but I personally dislike slide style match 3. However I am aware that others do.

Also be aware this game is apparently a port of the IOS version.

reviewText: 10,000,000 is a jaunty little puzzle/RPG game that is easy to play and addictively enjoyable. The plot is simple, you wake up in a dungeon cell and as the title of the game implies, you escape the dungeon for good when you score 10 million points in a single run. The game plays like bejeweled in that the player shuffles tiles on a grid by dragging a row or column in order to make 3 symbols match. Successful matches yields attacks, magic, keys, items, gold and materials that you can use to improve your cell, converting it into a base of operations which provides better gear, perks and special potions. The gameplay is easily accessable and there is a method to process of running dungeons that might feel hectic and challenging but never really feels frustrating. An average dungeon run takes only a few minutes but you can run the dungeon as many times as you like before returning to your base. The graphics are simple and have a Commodore 64 quality to them and the chiptune music is nicely composed.\n\n10,000,000 is simple, fun, and addictive. Easy to pick up and play, yet challenging when you want it to be. The price is very reasonable and the game is not graphically heavy so you can play it on an older machine. I really enjoyed this game and I think you might too.

10,000,000 is an action puzzle game, wherein your character's actions are determined by the tiles you line up in the Bejeweled-esque grid. 3 or more swords? He attacks the monster! Staves? Magic attack! Wood? He...gets wood.

Yes, there are materials, and they're used as sort of...filler spots in the puzzle game, it feels. But, they're used to upgrade the hero, leveling up his sword, staff, armor, etc. The actual game is very frantic, as you're constantly under threat of being killed by...what can best be described as an invisible countdown. The screen keeps scrolling as you fight a monster, or try to open a door, and only by completing the challenge (match up keys to open the door, match up attacks to kill the monster, etc) can he dash forward, regaining some time. Eventually you fight the boss, and win, or die and start back at your cell.

It's a fun game, I feel. A little short, (you'll notice, I beat it handily in under 10 hours, the rest were getting trading cards) but good in bursts. Occasionally, you may have a little trouble with the mouse controls, and the monsters may feel OP (one is, in fact, designed that way. I love the little bits of interest on some trading cards!), but it's not the most challenging game of 2013.

The reason is the upgrades you build up over plays. It felt a little lax here; you don't -really- get new swords through loot drops or anything. You spend wood, gold and EXP to upgrade your original equipment. So, be prepped for gathering loads of those materials to get somewhat unsatisfying upgrades as you go. You don't find an awesome staff that kills things easier, you play until you you can level it up that way.

Regardless, the core game is very enjoyable, and reminiscent of Puzzle Quest, if you were on a death-clock. It sounds bad, being rushed while trying to puzzle, but I think that's part of what lends charm and challenge to the game.

In short, I smell chicken cooking, and 10,000,000 is a really fun game.

10,000,000 essentially takes the core gameplay concept of Chuzzle (dragging whole rows and columns to make  a match) and adds classic RPG elements. It's easy to pick up, and it's not TOO hard to put down. If you like slow-paced contemplative tile-matching that make take you an hour to complete a run, this is gonna be a little much for you.

It is expected that each run will only last a short time (a minute or two in the early stages), because you are working against the clock. Your hero runs through a long dungeon (displayed at the top of the screen) and meets various obstacles. The type of obstacle will determine what type of match will allow you to advance. The hero runs fast enough to regain time, but the screen keeps scrolling slowly while you are working on an obstacle.

Doors and treasure chests require that you match Key tiles. Enemies can be attacked with Sword or Staff tiles. Most enemies will need to be attacked multiple times; they have health bars to let you know how you're doing. You must also endure enemies' attacks, which will reduce your timer (there is no HP, only the timer). Shield tiles can give you damage reduction, and Item tiles can generate useful consumable items for your inventory (one-use weapons and magic spells, keys, food to add time to the clock, etc).

You also match Wood and Stone tiles, which accumulate resources that are used back in your hub area in between dungeon runs. You build item shops which allow you to upgrade the effectiveness of each type of tile matches. You'll accumulate Gold and EXP with each dungeon run. Gold can be spent on your various tiered equpiment upgrades, and EXP can be spent on a variety of one-off permanent bonuses (like decreasing the cost of weapon upgrades, or granting bonus time for long combos).

You'll also be given up to three objectives to try to complete at the start of each run. These range from match [X number] of Stone tiles over the course of your run" to "defeat an enemy by only using Items"

I'm new to this match-3 game genre and I found the puzzle/rpg hybridness of 10,000,000 very addictive, even too much since I invested so much time on it to reach the 10 million points goal. But at last, freedom!

A blocking point for me was that it wasn't very obvious that rooms in addition of being unlocked could also be upgraded, so I got stuck at middle game wondering why I couldn't easily advance anymore as most monsters were kicking my back. Once I figured that out, completing the rest was rather easy. I guess that other people who complained the amount of grinding needed to win the game also incurred in the same problem.

This game isn't meant to be finished in a single sitting. It can get a bit repetitive after several tries, but if you limit it to a few ones a time, it will remain a fun game for quite a while.

Note that I played it on my PC with a Wacom graphics pen tablet, I guess it isn't as fun and easy to play with a mouse. 10,000,000 essentially takes the core gameplay concept of Chuzzle (dragging whole rows and columns to make  a match) and adds classic RPG elements. It's easy to pick up, and it's not TOO hard to put down. If you like slow-paced contemplative tile-matching that make take you an hour to complete a run, this is gonna be a little much for you.

It is expected that each run will only last a short time (a minute or two in the early stages), because you are working against the clock. Your hero runs through a long dungeon (displayed at the top of the screen) and meets various obstacles. The type of obstacle will determine what type of match will allow you to advance. The hero runs fast enough to regain time, but the screen keeps scrolling slowly while you are working on an obstacle.

Doors and treasure chests require that you match Key tiles. Enemies can be attacked with Sword or Staff tiles. Most enemies will need to be attacked multiple times; they have health bars to let you know how you're doing. You must also endure enemies' attacks, which will reduce your timer (there is no HP, only the timer). Shield tiles can give you damage reduction, and Item tiles can generate useful consumable items for your inventory (one-use weapons and magic spells, keys, food to add time to the clock, etc).

You also match Wood and Stone tiles, which accumulate resources that are used back in your hub area in between dungeon runs. You build item shops which allow you to upgrade the effectiveness of each type of tile matches. You'll accumulate Gold and EXP with each dungeon run. Gold can be spent on your various tiered equpiment upgrades, and EXP can be spent on a variety of one-off permanent bonuses (like decreasing the cost of weapon upgrades, or granting bonus time for long combos).

You'll also be given up to three objectives to try to complete at the start of each run. These range from match [X number] of Stone tiles over the course of your run" to "defeat an enemy by only using Items"

I got this game on a whim during it's 0.99 cent sale. At the time, I was suffering from a very painful toothache, which was almost dehibilitating. I wanted something I could do that didn't require focus, so I figured I'd try this game. Two things of note; one, my estimate for not requiring focus was completely off-base. Two, I played it from install to near completion in one 5 hour sitting. My toothache was an afterthought. I have no more praiseworthy sentence than that.

The concept is simple; it's a match-3 game. Even worse, it's my least favorite kind of match-3 game; a move has to end with 3 or more matching. Nothing akin to, say, Tetris Attack, where you could meticulously plot out an amazing chain, one block move at a time. So why would I recommend this game, even when the first two paragraphs of this review are faintly condemning it?

Because it's amazing, that's why. It takes cue from other match-3 games with the simple but addictive gameplay, and then adds it's own finess to the mix. You're exploring a dungeon, and your actions are based on matching tiles. Clear 3 Key tiles to open a lock on a treasure chest, match 3 Sword tiles to swing a sword at an enemy, you get the idea. Run the dungeon as long as you can, slaying enemies, collecting loot, and get as far as you can. Strive for that 10,000,000-point mark.

What makes this work so well is it's so frantic. At any given time, you're matching in the grid, while watching your inventory of special, one-shot items, while at the same time plotting for the next encounter. Fighting a dragon? Forget those keys, those wood, you need lots and lots of attacks. At a chest? Those swords do you no good, you're waisting them as only keys will open the locks. Well well well, where to start with this game?

Awhile back I heard about 10,000,000 and I was looking forward to getting my hands on it to play, after I got it, I spent 2 or 3 hours playing it nonstop, soon after my play session ended I relised I felt really weird,  so I tryed to stand up, and I felt so disorentated dizzy to almost the point where I felt intoxicated, I couldnt understand it.

That aside, the time spent playing 10,000,000 has had its frustraitons, but it was very fun, what ever it may be, getting huge combos going, to the silly hints, everything about it brings such a retro feel, the music and audio compliments the game.

In a nutshell, the top side scroller looking area of the screen is a cleverly disguised timer and health bar. Your character runs through a dungeon, and all of his actions are controlled by the blocks you match. Need to unlock a door or a chest? Match some keys. A monster blocking your path? Physical attacks are executed by matching swords while magical attacks fire off by matching staves. Standing still by not matching causes the timer to tick down, pushing your character to the left, and getting hit by monsters also pushes you to the left. The damage aspect can be mitigated by matching shields, which are absorbed instead of pushing your character. Fall off the side of the screen and it's game over.

To supplement these mechanics are a set of shockingly deep loot, item, upgrade, and experience systems. Monsters can drop loot, and you can also get loot by matching backpack tiles or unlocking chests. Loot can either be gold to buy upgrades or actual usable items. A few items you'll come across are a red orb that'll damage whatever monster is in front of you, a key to instantly unlock a chest or doorway blocking your path, scrolls to spawn more tiles of a certain type on the board, and much more.

This game is just sliding tiles. It tries to seem like more with the RPG elements but that is little more than a skin. The game rewards you for making as many matches as possible, as fast as possible, regardless of what is happening in the top section. Sure, you have to match the right tiles to proceed past each obstacle, but that happens naturally through frantic matching. If you try to play the board strategically you'll find things simply don't happen fast enough and you'll fail the level because time is always ticking down and you HP usually is too. The whole experience feels like it was designed by a gambling cartel trying to get me addicted to slots.

The upgrade system was compelling at first but quite quickly became a chore and no longer enhances the experience after a few hours. There is a little strategic freedom in how you spend your resources on upgrades and perks but it really doesn't affect gameplay, it just shifts difficulty from one element to another. There is also an arbitrary wait while upgrades are occurring in which you can't do anything but watch the progress bar. This wait increases with each upgrade for no reason. It isn't long but it is completely unnecessary. The investment type perks are pointless because they effectively just adjust how much grinding is necessary and players won't know how much grinding they want to do until they've missed the opportunity for the investment to be economically viable. I honestly think they game would be better served by automating or removing the entire upgrade system and just implementing a few sliders so players can adjust how good they have to be at tile matching to not lose.

The only thing which is still interesting after a few hours is the challenges. There are at most 3 challenges active at any time and new challenges aren't made available until space is made for them by completing an existing challenge. They are things like 'Kill an armored monster with only staves' and 'Open a chest within 5 seconds'. Challenges provide a reason to adjust strategy which helps stop the game becoming stale, however I'm fairly frequently stuck on (a) challenge(s) and the game stops being fun at all. Completing an overly difficult challenge is a relief, not a reward, because a combination of grinding and luck is what gets me there. An option to skip challenges would fix this but might reduce the worth of the challenge system.

To put it simply, if you're expecting anything more from the game than a pretty good tile matching time-waster you might be disappointed. I think there is potential in the format but a lot more weight needs to be given to the RPG elements for me to enjoy this as a hybrid puzzle RPG and not just a puzzle game with a guy running at the top of the screen.

This is a puzzle game at heart. If you line up 3 or more coloured tiles they disappear from the grid, they disappear. In much the same fashion as Bejeweled, new tiles then fall down from the top of the grid to fill in the now empty space. The only way this differs from Bejeweled is that instead of swapping two tiles, you instead can drag any row left or right, or any column up or down in its entirety to make a match.

However, this is only half of the game, and is frankly the boring bit. Each set of tiles you clear does something different, with the aim of keeping your man running through the dungeon above the board as long as possible. So sword and staff attack monsters, shield defends you, keys open locks, backpack provides items, and wood and stone help you upgrade your base. So this balance of keeping the right tiles on the screen, especially when different monsters are weaker to different attacks, is what keeps this game enthralling.

That said, it does have some problems with artificial difficulty. Your health/stamina is represented by how far along the top of the screen your man is. Once this runs out, you have to restart the level for another try at the high score. However, as your man runs through the dungeon, the time it takes to slide backwards along the track  gets shorter and shorter, decreasing your max health no matter how well you are playing. As a result, you often need to start at a later checkpoint to have any chance of progressing to a higher score. I'd have much preferred just a straight run through increasing power/health monsters than a backwards slide down my character's own abilities.

So overall:
Negatives:
The match game is Bejeweled and requires little strategy.
Decreasing power through out a run gets on my nerves.
Positives:
The dungeon combat system is inspired and brings the strategy that Bejeweled lacks.
The power increase due to upgrades between runs is well thought through and well paced.

If this game had an endless mode, that is a mode where monster health/attack power went up constantly until you die, I'd recommend this in an instant.
But without this it lacks replay value as you feel like you're hitting a hard-coded wall instead of the limits of your own ability.

So a reasonable game for 3$, is enjoyable, just don't expect too much playtime from it.  7/10

Let me just say that I only BARELY recommend this game, and that you would really do yourself a service getting this game while it's on sale or something.

Main premise:
The point of this game is to reach a score of 10,000,000. This is done by playing a Chuzzle-esque tile match game wherein the tiles you match has an outcome on a dungeon battle. If you by example matches 3 tiles of a sword the guy attacks, 3 keys and you can open chests and doors, 3 wood or stone and you get resources to upgrade later in the game. The game include upgrades, shops, potions, bosses, and a suprisingly big number of valuables (experience, wood, stone, points, and money).

Graphics/Sound:
The game originated on phones and tablets and you can definitely tell that by a lot of factors. First of all the graphics are in a very heavy and sometimes grating 8-bit style and the sounds and music are entirely in chiptunes. The chiptunes are not bad by any means, but they're put on a short loop and they can get rather repetitive and annoying. It's not a game that needs to be great looking or sound amazing. It does its job, with average success.

Gameplay:
This is a grinding puzzle game. The main point is to get as far as possible and then retry again and again, until you can buy more upgrades and get a little further into the game until you reach the target score. This is a slow moving process. There really isn't much progress in terms of mechanics. All mechanics of the game is presented in the first 30-45 minutes and then the question is if you actually want to continue doing the same thing for a few hours.

The main problem here, is that the game does a very poor job at spacing apart and adding game mechanics as you go along so everything feels fresh. This makes the game stagnate pretty quickly, and you get bored by it easily. You can only play this game in short bursts.

This game has two parts to it; the action-puzzle part, and the management/upgrade/RPG-ish part. The first part, is mostly pretty well executed. The tiles do what they do, and you can most of the time tell that a bad run was mostly because that you didn't do well. The game can be a bit unfair in the distribution of different tiles, giving you 3 key tiles in total, when you really need it, but other than that, the nature of the game makes it difficult enough to be challenging, but forgiving enough to not be frustrated.

The problems with the game originates from the second part, which is poorly executed. It has the growing of character RPG elements. You know, you start out as a weakling, but then you become stronger and stronger the more you play. Except that this game makes you not feel like progressing at all. It's hard to describe, but I got the same feeling out of playing Defiance. Despite constantly leveling up and progressing to the next level, and fighting tougher enemies and buying more upgrades and improving your various weaponry, it doesn't really feel like you're making a difference. Well, maybe a little, but 2 hours in the game, you don't feel that your character has gotten that much stronger since last. I speculate, that this is because that the core game (the tile game) does not become easier or harder, only the outcome becomes greater.

This, together with repetitious gameplay, makes the game stale after longer amounts of play.

Story:
This game does not really have a story, and for a game like this, it's fine without.

Replayability/Concept:
I really like the concept, and I feel that with a bit more tweaking and tuning this game could have been a lot more fun and a lot more addictive, which it isn't now, because of the repetitive nature of the game. There is also a bit of originality by this concept, mixing two genres together only really done well in PuzzleQuest.
Other than achievements, there is no real reason to start over and try again.

Length and fun factor:
To be honest, I haven't beaten it yet, but judging by where I am at right now, I estimate a total play time of 3-6 hours.
I find the core game (the tile puzzle game) to be very entertaining. It's hectic and it's stimulating, however it's hard finding joy in having to do this, let's be honest here, primitive game over and over again just to feel a bit of evolution and progress.

Final Thoughts and judgement:
If you are a big puzzle fan, especially of things like Chuzzle, PuzzleQuest, Bejeweled or even Candy Crush, and looking for a simple tile game with even simpler RPG elements over it, then this is recommendable. The puzzle aspect is fun, and if you're into that, the RPG part will not totally ruin it for you. For anyone else this is hard to recommend. For what it's worth I have found entertainment in this game, but some of the core aspects are flawed.

If you like puzzle games and you see this on a sale it couldn't hurt to get this (and therefore earning my thumbs up). There are just much better alternatives.

10,000,000 essentially takes the core gameplay concept of Chuzzle (dragging whole rows and columns to make  a match) and adds classic RPG elements. It's easy to pick up, and it's not TOO hard to put down. If you like slow-paced contemplative tile-matching that make take you an hour to complete a run, this is gonna be a little much for you.

It is expected that each run will only last a short time (a minute or two in the early stages), because you are working against the clock. Your hero runs through a long dungeon (displayed at the top of the screen) and meets various obstacles. The type of obstacle will determine what type of match will allow you to advance. The hero runs fast enough to regain time, but the screen keeps scrolling slowly while you are working on an obstacle.

Doors and treasure chests require that you match Key tiles. Enemies can be attacked with Sword or Staff tiles. Most enemies will need to be attacked multiple times; they have health bars to let you know how you're doing. You must also endure enemies' attacks, which will reduce your timer (there is no HP, only the timer). Shield tiles can give you damage reduction, and Item tiles can generate useful consumable items for your inventory (one-use weapons and magic spells, keys, food to add time to the clock, etc).

You also match Wood and Stone tiles, which accumulate resources that are used back in your hub area in between dungeon runs. You build item shops which allow you to upgrade the effectiveness of each type of tile matches. You'll accumulate Gold and EXP with each dungeon run. Gold can be spent on your various tiered equpiment upgrades, and EXP can be spent on a variety of one-off permanent bonuses (like decreasing the cost of weapon upgrades, or granting bonus time for long combos).

You'll also be given up to three objectives to try to complete at the start of each run. These range from match [X number] of Stone tiles over the course of your run" to "defeat an enemy by only using Items"

There are also challenges to help you as well but completing them can be awfully obnoxious.

So the gameplay itself is a puzzle/RPG, you have to match tiles to either get resources for building new structres, attack enemies, use magic, get keys to unlock chests and doors and complete challenges to either earn more points or gain gold to make stronger items or train to gain new abilities.

There aren’t too many puzzle games that do what this one does. While it at first might seem like a simple match-4 game with some fantasy elements thrown in, there is so much more below the surface. 10,000,000 is a puzzle game that focuses on upgradeable equipment, dungeon running, resource collecting, and finishing quests. Now, I don’t know about you, but there aren’t too many puzzle games that come to mind that can check off those same boxes. This game does something very special: it makes you want to solve puzzles, not just to get to the next level, but to progress in every sense of the term. Your character will gain access to better weapons, shields, and even potions which help all help customize the experience. 10,000,000 does all of this while being wrapped in a very basic pixel-art shell with music that is guaranteed to be stuck in your head for days.

This is a 'Match 3' style game doubling up as a dungeon crawler. It's deceptively simple in its artstyle, UI and objectives but it has a 'Just 1 more go' feedback loop that makes it maddeningly addictive. Match swords for physical attacks, Wands for Magical attacks, Shields for defence and resources to build your home base which unlocks upgrades.

Each run only lasts a matter of minutes but with every failure you earn a little more to upgrade your character and eventually hit the magical 10,000,000 which wins the game.

It's a perfect budget game. Easy to grasp premise and concept, mechanically excellent and a fun little diversion.

82/100
